user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_StoreRetval:
```c
bool UT_StoreRetval(UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize, UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre)
{
    /* Copy the value based on width, so it will be properly extended, if applicable:
     * - all numeric values need to be aligned per endianness of the host
     * - signed ints must be sign-extended,
     * - single-precision floating points will be extended to double-precision
     *
     * Pointers must all be the expected size, however.
     */
    switch (UT_GENRE_SIZE(ValueGenre, ValueSize))
    {
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int8)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int8 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int16)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int16 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int32)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int32 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int64)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int64 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(float)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((float const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((double const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_POINTER, sizeof(void *)):
            Buf->Ptr = *((void *const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        default:
            return UtAssert_Failed("Cannot store return value - ValueSize not valid");
    }

    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_StoreRetval:
#define UT_GENRE_SIZE(g, s) (((size_t)g<<8)|s)
...
typedef enum UT_ValueGenre
{
    UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE  = 0, /**< The nature of the value is opaque, reference is stored directly (NOT copied!) */
    UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER = 1, /**< The value is an integer and may be converted to integers of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT   = 2, /**< The value is a floating point and may be converted to floats of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_POINTER = 3  /**< The value is a pointer and should only be used to fulfill a pointer return */
} UT_ValueGenre_t
...
typedef int8_t    int8
...
typedef int16_t   int16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef int64_t   int64
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA Rule 14.3 applies to controlling expressions of conditional and iterative constructs. The only controlling construct in this function is the switch statement; therefore the switch controlling expression is listed as suspicious. The case labels (constant expressions) are included so reviewers can inspect whether the combined encoding (UT_GENRE_SIZE macro with sizeof values) could make the controlling expression effectively invariant for some inputs or lead to unintended constant behavior. Other fragments (assignments to Buf fields, breaks, the return statements, type casts, and the macro/typedef definitions) are not controlling expressions and thus are not relevant to Rule 14.3. There are no loops or if-statements in this function; the allowed exceptions for invariant controlling expressions (infinite loops, or the do-while constant-false exception) do not apply here.
